dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, we've been looking at this fascinating piece, and it really highlights this pretty stark contrast in productivity growth between the US and the Eurozone over the past two decades.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, we've been looking at this fascinating piece, and it really highlights this pretty stark contrast in productivity growth between the U S and the Eurozone over the past two decades.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two decades since 2004, US productivity growth, as measured by the value of output per hour worked, has been more than double that of the eurozone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's wild, right? Like, since 2004, the US has basically doubled the Eurozone's productivity growth. And since COVID, the US is up over 6%, while, um, Europe's kinda flatlined, even fallen a bit.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two decades since 2004, US productivity growth, as measured by the value of output per hour worked, has been more than double that of the eurozone. Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously. It's like, what's going on? Is the US just doing everything right, and Europe, you know, everything wrong?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously. It's like, what's going on? Is the U S just doing everything right, and Europe, you know, everything wrong?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, some folks, especially in Europe, like to think it's all about the US's massive fiscal stimulus, right? All that government spending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, some folks, especially in Europe, like to think it's all about the U S's massive fiscal stimulus, right? All that government spending.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some accounts point to the strong fiscal stimulus applied in the US since the outbreak of the pandemic. For Europeans this explanation is reassuring, because it suggests that the differential is transitory.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the idea being, "Oh, it's just a temporary boost." But the article kinda pushes back on that. Why would stimulus inherently drive *productivity* growth? If anything, you might hire less productive workers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the idea being, Oh, it's just a temporary boost. But the article kinda pushes back on that. Why would stimulus inherently drive productivity growth? If anything, you might hire less productive workers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But while strong spending stimulus can trigger rapid output and employment growth, it is not clear why it should produce faster productivity growth. On the contrary, given strong employment growth and tight labor markets, one might expect US companies to be forced to take on less productive workers, with negative implications for output per hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Yeah, exactly! Like, you'd think with tight labor markets, companies might have to bring on anyone, which, uh, could actually *lower* output per hour.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! Like, you'd think with tight labor markets, companies might have to bring on anyone, which, uh, could actually lower output per hour.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the contrary, given strong employment growth and tight labor markets, one might expect US companies to be forced to take on less productive workers, with negative implications for output per hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But then, the flip side of those tight labor markets... firms, maybe they can't find enough people, so they're forced to invest in technology, right? Like, labor-saving tech.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then, the flip side of those tight labor markets... firms, maybe they can't find enough people, so they're forced to invest in technology, right? Like, labor-saving tech.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More likely, tight labor markets in the US may mean that firms, unable to find an adequate supply of workers at any price, are impelled to substitute capital for labor to invest in labor-saving technology.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. Think about it. Go to a US bank, it's all ATMs, no tellers. QR codes for ordering food, even at fancy restaurants. You know, that's capital substituting for labor.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally. Think about it. Go to a U S bank, it's all A T Ms, no tellers. Q R codes for ordering food, even at fancy restaurants. You know, that's capital substituting for labor.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans visiting a bank branch will encounter plenty of ATMs but sometimes not a single human teller. They are compelled to order meals, even at white-tablecloth restaurants, using a QR code.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, though the article points out this US outperformance actually started *before* the pandemic, when labor markets weren't quite so tight. So, it's not the full story.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, though the article points out this U S outperformance actually started before the pandemic, when labor markets weren't quite so tight. So, it's not the full story.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recall, however, that US productivity growth had accelerated relative to Europes already in the decade leading up to the pandemic, when labor markets were not so tight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, if it's not *just* that, then what about Europe? What's holding them back, or, um, going wrong over there?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, if it's not just that, then what about Europe? What's holding them back, or, um, going wrong over there?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it brings up a few things. Strong trade unions potentially resisting new tech, fearing job losses. Or, like, restrictive EU rules, especially around data privacy and AI.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it brings up a few things. Strong trade unions potentially resisting new tech, fearing job losses. Or, like, restrictive E U rules, especially around data privacy and A I.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could be that Europes strong trade unions, fearing job destruction, resist their adoption... Alternatively, restrictive European Union rules may be impeding adoption. The EUs data-privacy regulations, and now its proposed AI rulebook, if adhered to strictly, may slow the development of AI applications.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] And then there's the big one, right? Just plain bad luck with Putin and the energy crisis. The US is energy self-sufficient, but Europe got hammered.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the big one, right? Just plain bad luck with Putin and the energy crisis. The U S is energy self-sufficient, but Europe got hammered.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finally, it could simply be that Europe has had bad luck, specifically in the form of Russian President Vladimir Putin and his energy-price shock. The US, being self-sufficient in energy, has not been vulnerable to energy-supply disruptions to the same degree.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. I mean, forcing companies to suspend energy-intensive ops or costly restructuring? That's, uh, not great for productivity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. I mean, forcing companies to suspend energy-intensive ops or costly restructuring? That's, uh, not great for productivity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: European firms, in contrast, have been forced to suspend their most energy-intensive operations or else to engage in costly restructuring, which is not good for productivity.

dialogue_turns.text: So, what's the plan for Europe then? Mario Draghi, he's apparently got some ideas coming out.

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but the article says these are, you know, pretty old ideas. Like completing the capital-markets union, removing barriers to competition, boosting energy self-sufficiency.
